I have never rooted a symmetrical pieces and would never expect it to work. So many things get automatically applied to symmetry that I would expect Root to fail. Just don't do it. It's not a bug, it's a KSP feature.

I have found a very serious bug (which my be my fault for using SelectRoot incorrectly, but the bug is so serious that it doesn't matter). The trigger for the bug is bringing in multiple subassemblies which have been SelectRooted to normally non-rootable parts (usually a docking port, ejector, or stack decoupler). When you combine them into one ship, and you try to selectroot anything *or* you try and launch the ship, KSP will simply consume memory loading and re-loading until it runs out.

I can repeat this bug. I will try to get a simpler test case that involves the minimum number of parts and get back to here.
Simple solution: don't do that. Put a dummy probe on top and strip it out during assembly. What you're experiencing is KSP putting a foot down and getting confused.
